name: Hera
subtitle: Queen of the Gods, Goddess of Marriage and Family
description:
Hera stands as one of the most iconic and influential figures in Greek mythology. Revered as the deity of Marriage, women, childbirth, Hera embodies the fundamental forces that shape both the divine and mortal realms. Known as "Queen of the Gods, Goddess of Marriage and Family", this epithet captures the essence of their divine nature. 

According to Greek sacred texts, Hera's origins trace back to the primordial age, emerging from the cosmic struggle between Titans and Olympians The worship of Hera became central to Greek religious practice, with devotees seeking their favor through temple sacrifices, libations, and participation in sacred festivals. 

Sacred symbols associated with Hera include Diadem (crown), scepter, peacock. These emblems appear throughout Greek art and literature, serving as powerful reminders of Hera's divine presence and authority. The mythology surrounding Hera reveals deep insights into Greek worldview, particularly concerning Marriage and humanity's relationship with the divine. 

The legacy of Hera extends far beyond ancient Greek civilization. References to Hera pervade Western literature, from Renaissance poetry to modern novels. The archetype continues to influence psychology, philosophy, and popular culture Scholars continue to study Hera's mythology for its profound insights into Greek culture, religion, and philosophy.

topic_panels.title: Worship & Practice
topic_panels.content:
### Religious Practice

Worship of Hera involved temple sacrifices, festivals, oracles. These practices created sacred bonds between devotees and the divine realm.

### Sacred Sites

Throughout Ancient Greece, Mediterranean basin, temples and shrines dedicated to Hera served as focal points for religious activity. Priests and priestesses maintained sacred rituals that ensured divine favor and cosmic balance.

### Festivals & Ceremonies

Special festivals celebrated Hera's divine attributes and mythological deeds, bringing communities together in shared religious expression.
